newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia urges improved ASEAN customs procedures.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia urges improved ASEAN customs procedures.

text.p: Indonesian Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad on Wednesday urged customs officials in Southeast Asian countries to improve their administrations and smooth the flow of trade.

Directors-general of customs of the seven-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) opened a two-day meeting in the Indonesian capital to review the progress in improving the handling of cross-border trade.

"Ensuring that customs administration supports legitimate economic activities and ensures a smooth flow of goods across our national boundaries is crucial to our efforts to create a stronger ASEAN," Mar'ie said in an address delivered on his behalf.
He said customs continued to have a crucial role in effectively and fairly applying existing tariffs and enforcing rules against smuggling and illegal trade.
They also had to improve their work "to ensure that customs administration is not seen as a bottleneck to investment and production".
ASEAN Secretary-General Ajit Singh said progress had already been made in such areas as harmonising tariff nomenclature, valuation and procedures.
Other enhancements under way include a common customs form, the green lane system to speed up the clearance of goods, and the drafting of an ASEAN agreement on customs.
Singh noted that ASEAN was the world's fourth-biggest trading entity, with imports and exports of more than $500 billion in 1994.

"Efficient customs administrations with simplified, transparent and predictable customs procedures will certainly reduce costs and enable the private sector to function more smoothly and effectively," he said.
ASEAN comprises Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Brunei and the Philippines.
